channel.title: Nature
channel.description: Nature is the foremost international weekly scientific journal in the world and is the flagship journal for Nature Portfolio. It publishes the finest peer-reviewed research in all fields of science and technology on the basis of its originality, importance, interdisciplinary interest, timeliness, accessibility, elegance and surprising conclusions. Nature publishes landmark papers, award winning news, leading comment and expert opinion on important, topical scientific news and events that enable readers to share the latest discoveries in science and evolve the discussion amongst the global scientific community.
channel.dc:rights: © 2025 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.

item.title: Thirty years of Bose–Einstein condensation
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 November 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03592-6

In 1995, two papers reported long-sought proof of an exotic state of matter — with applications in fields as diverse as quantum computing and cosmology.
item.dc:title: Thirty years of Bose–Einstein condensation
item.dc:creator: Zoran Hadzibabic
Ulrich Schneider

item.title: Author Correction: A metallic p-wave magnet with commensurate spin helix

Author Correction: A metallic p-wave magnet with commensurate spin helix

item.title: Electro-generated excitons for tunable lanthanide electroluminescence
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09717-1

The electroluminescence emitted from lanthanide fluoride nanocrystals functionalized with ligands is shown to be tunable, providing a method for exciton control in insulating nanocrystal systems and offering a pathway for spectrally precise electroluminescent materials.
item.dc:title: Electro-generated excitons for tunable lanthanide electroluminescence
item.dc:creator: Jing Tan
Peng Zhang
Xiaoqing Song
Chunmiao Han
Feng Wang
Jing Zhang
Chunbo Duan
Zhilong Zhang
Sanyang Han
Hui Xu
Xiaogang Liu

item.title: Triplets electrically turn on insulating lanthanide-doped nanoparticles
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09601-y

To turn on and obtain emission from lanthanide-doped insulating nanoparticles, an electrical excitation pathway coupling them to organic optical molecules to form nanohybrids is described, enabling tunable electroluminescence properties of LEDs fabricated from such materials.
item.dc:title: Triplets electrically turn on insulating lanthanide-doped nanoparticles
item.dc:creator: Zhongzheng Yu
Yunzhou Deng

item.title: Topological nodal i-wave superconductivity in PtBi2
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09712-6

Angle-resolved photoemission spectroscopy shows that Weyl semimetal PtBi2 harbours nodes in its superconducting gap, implying unconventional i-wave pairing symmetry.
item.dc:title: Topological nodal i-wave superconductivity in PtBi2
item.dc:creator: Susmita Changdar
Oleksandr Suvorov
Andrii Kuibarov

item.title: Lanthanides go electric: promising light emitters used in LEDs
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 November 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03586-4

Nanoparticles containing lanthanide ions are excellent light emitters. The addition of organic molecules means that they can be activated using electric currents.
item.dc:title: Lanthanides go electric: promising light emitters used in LEDs
item.dc:creator: P. James Schuck
